    Each customer subscribing to use the sewer service of the city shall pay a connection fee in an amount established by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-2.1. - Island annexations. 
(a)  Island annexations. In the case of property owners annexed into the city after May 1, 1996, and required to pay the sewer connection fees described in section 11-2 above in connection with the annexation of property into the city under O.C.G.A. § 36-36-90 et seq., the mayor and council may allow payment as follows: 
(1)  May allow payment in no more than twenty-four (24) equal monthly installments; or 
(2)  May defer payment until such time as: 
a.  The property owner desires or is required to connect to the sewer system; or 
b.  The property is transferred by sale, gift, devise or any other method of transfer. 
(b)  Under no circumstances may the city issue any permit to repair or extend any septic system within an area where sewer service is available. In all circumstances in which the mayor and council elect to allow deferral of sewer connection fees, the property owner shall sign and consent to a "Notice of Sewer Connection Fees," which shall be filed upon the public deed records of Cobb County, Georgia, and shall act as a lien upon the property, which must be satisfied prior to any transfer. 
(c)  Each property owner annexed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-36-90 et seq. shall notify the city within sixty (60) days of the effective date of annexation of his or her intent to request deferred payment of sewer connection fees under subsection (a) above. Failure to timely notify the city of intent to request deferral shall operate as a waiver of any right to request deferral. 
(d)  In the event a property owner annexed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-36-90 et seq. elects to pay the required sewer connection fee in full, or elects to immediately begin payment in installments pursuant to subsection (a)(1) above, the mayor and council are authorized, but not required, to waive the sewer line fee required by Code subsection 11-11(b). The mayor and council shall not be authorized to waive the line fee required by subsection 11-11(b) in the event a property owner elects to defer the sewer connection fee pursuant to subsection (a)(2)a. or (a)(2)b. of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-3. - Water and sewer rate schedule. 
(a)  Rate schedule. A water and sewer rate schedule for the city shall be adopted by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Rates for services. A service rate schedule for the following services shall be adopted by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk: 
(1)  Disconnect fee: This fee is incurred when an account has been cut off due to delinquency. Once payment is paid in full, along with the bill amount and any applicable after hours fee, the service is restored. 
(2)  After hours reconnect fee: This fee is incurred when service has been disconnected due to delinquency and payment is not received before 4:00 p.m. 
(3)  Service call: This fee is incurred when service personnel are required to make more than two (2) trips to an address to accomplish a task. 
(4)  Reread fee: This fee is incurred when a customer requests the meter to be reread, after service personnel had previously checked on the edit list and found no problem. 
(5)  Meter calibration fee: This fee is incurred when a customer requests the meter to be calibrated. Calibration requires dispatch of service personnel to the property, removal of the meter, delivery to public works for testing and calibration, and installation following the test. 
(6)  Return check fee: This fee is incurred when a check is returned for payment of any water bill or service. The customer will be provided two (2) business days to pick up the check and pay with cash, credit card or money order for the amount of the bill and all associated service fees. If the bill and fees are not paid within two (2) business days, the water service will be disconnected and the customer shall be assessed a disconnect fee. 
(7)  Notification fee: This fee is incurred when a service man is dispatched with a notice to the residence, such as a final notice on the account before service is disconnected or to notify of a return check. 
(8)  Credit card payment fee: This fee is incurred when a customer pays by credit card over the phone. 
(d)  Deposits for service. Each customer shall pay a deposit for services in an amount established by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(1)  Return of deposit. Except for the cart fee, and after twenty-four (24) months of payment without penalties, the deposit will be refunded when the customer moves or upon written request by the customer. The customer will be assessed another deposit at a new location in the city if the customer received a final notice on the previous account more than three (3) times in twelve (12) months. 
(2)  Rental property. If a property owner resides inside the city's water boundary and has an account in good standing, no deposit is required to place water service in the property owner's name until the property can be cleaned and rented. If an owner does not reside in the city's water boundary, the owner shall make a deposit in the amount established by resolution, but is only required to make one (1) deposit for multiple addresses. 
(3)  A deposit normally collected at application for service may be waived by the city manager if the finance director presents evidence that the applicant is a previous utility customer who received city utility services for a period of at least thirty-six (36) consecutive months without penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10; Ord. No. 2015-030, 11-19-15) 
Sec. 11-4. - Billings; collecting. 
(a)  Bills to customers for water service, sewer service and/or solid waste collection service shall be mailed out on such days each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at the city hall and a failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent or relieve the consumer from payment of same. The failure of the user to pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic disconnection of service if payment has not been made within thirty (30) days after same is due. 
(b)  Service discontinued for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, such security deposit as may be required is made, and a service charge in an amount established by resolution is paid for each meter disconnected. 
(c)  All water, sewer and solid waste collection fees shall be due within fifteen (15) days from date of issuance of the bill. 
(d)  All water and sewer tap on fees shall be paid prior to the date of the issuance of the tap permit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-5. - Access to premises and extensions of system. 
(a)  Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service and its facilities, and the sewer service and its facilities. 
(b)  Extensions to the system shall be made only when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the city a permanent easement right-of-way across any property traversed by the water lines or sewer lines. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-6. - Change of occupancy. 
    Not less than three (3) days' notice must be given, in person or in writing, at the city hall to discontinue water and sewer service or to change occupancy. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all water consumed up to the time of departure or the time specified for departure, whichever period is longer. The new occupant shall apply for water service within forty-eight (48) hours after occupying the premises and failure to do so will make such person liable for paying for the water consumed since the last meter reading. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-7. - Suspension of service. 
(a)  Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills or on request of consumer, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for the collection of debts. 
(b)  The city reserves a right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: 
(1)  To prevent fraud or abuse; 
(2)  Consumer's willful disregard of the city's rules; 
(3)  Emergency repairs; 
(4)  As to water, insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control; 
(5)  Legal processes; 
(6)  Direction of public authorities; or 
(7)  Strike, riot, fire, flood, or unavoidable accident. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-8. - Complaints; adjustments. 
    If the consumer believes a bill to be in error, such consumer shall present the claim, in person, at the city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest, and said payment shall not prejudice the claim. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-9. - Executions authorized; imposition of lien. 
    Should a customer for city water, sewer, solid waste collection service and/or street light service who is either the owner of property served or the agent of such owner not pay the municipal water, sewer, solid waste collection and/or street light charges thereon, and the payment thereof shall be in default for a period of ninety (90) days after the first date due, then the city shall be entitled and authorized to have an execution issue, which execution shall issue in the name of the city in rem against the property described and shown on the ad valorem tax digest, and in personam against the owner of the property and shall be for the principal amount due, plus interest at the rate of seven (7) percent per annum from the first date due, and the sum of the actual cost incurred for the issuance of the execution. Subsequent costs thereon shall be the same as those now or hereafter allowed by law to the sheriff for the performance of similar services. Such execution for municipal water, sewer, solid waste collection and/or street light service charges shall be delivered to the marshal of the city, and subsequent proceedings had thereon shall be as provided by law for the enforcement of executions for taxes. All executions issued pursuant hereto shall issue against the owner and the property served, and shall be recorded on the general execution docket of the clerk of superior court of this county, and the same shall constitute a lien against the property from the time the charge was first due, which lien shall rank on a parity with and be of equal dignity to other liens for special tax assessments. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-10. - Notice of lien. 
    If a default occurs in the payment of such sums as may be due for city water and sewer service by a customer who is either the owner of the property served or the agent of such owner, then notice shall be given to the owner of such property so served, as shown on the latest available ad valorem tax digest of the county, that the property so served is subject to a lien for such water, sewer and/or solid waste collection charges in the nature of a tax lien for special assessments. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-11. - Water and sewer line fees; required connection in new service area. 
(a)  This section shall apply to all water and sewer services located within the corporate limits of the city, as well as all areas served by the water and sewer system of the city whether within the corporate limits or without. 
(b)  In those cases where water or sewer service is available and in place, and a new building or existing building desires to tap into the water or sewer system, such property owner desiring to tap into the water or sewer system shall pay a line fee, which line fee shall be in addition to the meter fee or sewer tap fee. The line fee shall be an amount established by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. In those cases in which a property owner wishes water or sewer service but there is no water or sewer line presently existing, the property owner will be required to pay the complete cost of running the water or sewer line from the existing nearest service to such person's property line; provided however, that in the future should intervening property owners desire to tap onto the water or sewer system, the property owner initially running the line shall be entitled to a rebate of the cost of running the line; provided further, that the original property owner running the line shall not be entitled to a rebate less than the charges for such owner's individual service as described in the preceding paragraph. In those circumstances where the city presently has a water or sewer line but in order to service a new customer it is necessary to upgrade the size or quality of the water or sewer line, the cost of upgrading the water or sewer line shall be borne by the new customer for which the water or sewer upgrade is necessary. In no circumstances shall existing customers be required to bear the cost of the upgrade in size or quality. 
(c)  All new subdivisions within the corporate limits of the city or without the city but within the service areas as delineated by that certain Agreement for Wholesale Water Treatment Service and Retail Water and Wastewater Service Area Boundary with Cobb County dated August 13, 2007, as same may hereafter be amended, shall install sanitary sewer lines connected to the nearest sewer trunk lines. In those cases where sanitary sewer line service is available within three thousand (3,000) feet of any portion of the subdivision, the developer will be required to construct the line at such developer's sole and exclusive expense. If the available sanitary sewer connection is beyond three thousand (3,000) feet, the developer must install the trunk connecting line, but future connections to the trunk line shall be rebated to the developer for those costs in excess of three thousand (3,000) feet. 
(d)  All property owners within the service boundary as delineated by that certain Agreement for Wholesale Water Treatment Service and Retail Water and Wastewater Service Area Boundary with Cobb County dated August 13, 2007, as same may hereafter be amended, must connect to an existing sewer line if the sewer line is within two hundred (200) feet of any portion of such owner's property. If not available within two hundred (200) feet, a septic tank will be permitted, subject to approval by the Cobb County Health Department; however, a certificate and agreement must be signed by the property owner agreeing to connect the sewer system when it becomes available within two hundred (200) feet of his property. 
(e)  No commercial or industrial users or sewage generators which meet, and continue to meet, the following criteria shall be required to connect to the city's sewerage system: 
(1)  The total property area utilized by said user or sewerage generator shall not exceed two (2) acres. 
(2)  The total area of any and all buildings occupied by said user or sewage generator shall not exceed ten thousand (10,000) square feet. 
(3)  The total connected "fixture unit count" for such user or sewage generator, as defined in the state plumbing code, shall not exceed fifty (50) for buildings using flush type water closets, or thirty-five (35) for buildings using tank type water closets. 
(4)  The distance from the closet point on such user's or generator's property boundary to the nearest public sewer, exceeds two thousand (2,000) linear feet. In the event that public sewer should be constructed within five hundred (500) feet of such user's or sewage generator's property, said user or generator shall connect to public sewer within one hundred eighty (180) days of notification from the city. 
    All other commercial or industrial users or sewage generators shall conform to the same sewerage connection requirements as subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-12. - Construction of detention and retention ponds. 
    The following construction standards shall apply to any and all detention or retention ponds constructed within the city: 
(1)  All retention and detention ponds which exceed four (4) feet in depth, as measured vertically from the lowest point of the pond to the lowest point on the top of the dam, berm, or dike of the structure, shall be fenced with a chain link fence or privacy fence not less than six (6) feet in height. The type of fence shall be specified by the city manager at or before approval of the final subdivision plat. 
(2)  Posts for such fences shall be set on centers not less than ten (10) feet apart. 
(3)  All such fences shall have a minimum of one (1) ten-foot-wide gate for access, which gate shall remain locked at all times. 
(4)  Such fences shall be installed completely around the pond and any dike, dam, or berm forming a portion of the pond. No fence shall be installed across the slope of a dam, dike, or berm. 
(5)  An easement across private property to access the retention or detention pond shall be provided by each owner of property abutting or adjoining the pond. 
(6)  All retention and detention ponds shall be maintained by the owner or owners on whose property or properties the ponds exist. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-13. - Regulation of CATV rates. 
(a)  The city will follow the FCC rate regulations in its regulation of the basic service rates and charges of any cable television system operating in the city. 
(b)  In connection with such regulation, the city will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties. 
(c)  The mayor is authorized to execute on behalf of the city and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereinafter be required by the FCC rate regulations in order to enable the city to regulate basic service rates and charges. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-14. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11-15. - Adjustment of water rate due to leak. 
(a)  Any customer requesting adjusted rate credit for leak conditions shall show, to the satisfaction of the finance director, that leak has been repaired. Evidence of repair may include, but is not limited to, receipt of plumber for repair, affidavit of owner repair accompanied by receipt of materials; and 
(b)  Upon showing of repair, adjusted rate credit will be applied to water bills during leak period; however, adjustment period shall not exceed two (2) months; and 
(c)  The adjusted rate credit will be calculated as follows: the adjusted gallons will be multiplied by the regular rate minus the adjusted rate. 
(1)  The adjusted gallons will be calculated based on the actual gallons used during the leak period over and above the previous six (6) months' average used; and 
(2)  The adjusted rate will be one hundred fifty (150) percent of the wholesale rate for water purchased by the city; and 
(3)  All amounts of water less than or equal to the previous six (6) months' average shall be billed at the regular rate. 
(d)  The leak adjustment provided for in this section 11-15 may only be issued once per customer within any twelve-month period. 
(e)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, any customer qualifying for an adjusted water rate due to a leak shall receive a credit for the difference between the rate charged and the rate that would have normally been charged to said customer based on the customer's average consumption history. 
(f)  No credit is available for ponds, hot tubs, topping off or routine pool maintenance. Any credit issued for a pool is limited to a sewer credit only, calculated as volume used to fill the pool multiplied by the applicable sewer rate. No more than one (1) pool leak credit is issued per year and is only available for refilling the pool following a needed repair. The customer shall submit documentation of the repair and pool size with the application. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10; Ord. No. 2017-022 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 11-16. - Street light charges. 
    A rate schedule for street lights shall be established by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2010-52, § 1, 11-15-10) 
Secs. 11-17-11-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATERWORKS 

Sec. 11-20. - Meters-Furnishing; limitations on service. 
    The city shall in all cases furnish and maintain the necessary meters. The city's obligations and responsibility, however, shall not extend beyond the meter, and the city shall not furnish service or aid beyond the load side of any such meter. 
(Code 1972, § 4-503; Ord. No. 2010-22, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 11-21. - Use of single meter. 
(a)  Each separate customer and separate premises shall have a separate meter and a separate monthly bill. Water will not be supplied to more than one (1) house through a single meter. Except as otherwise provided in this section, each tenement shall be considered a separate house and a meter required therefor. Meter readings shall not be consolidated for the same customer at different premises or for several customers on the same or different premises. For all commercial and office buildings where a sprinkler system is installed which requires a separate water main connection, a separate meter of a type specified by the public works director will be required for monitoring the flow. 
(b)  The owner of buildings containing two (2) or more family dwelling units is prohibited from using a single water meter to service such units unless same is expressly provided by ordinance; no customer may permit water or wastewater service to be taken through his installation (water meter) into any other building or dwelling unit, whether owned by himself or another, or whether on his premises or elsewhere unless same is expressly provided by ordinance. 
(c)  With written authorization from the public works director, the owner of buildings containing two (2) or more family dwelling units or an integrated complex of buildings containing the same may elect to use a single water meter ("master meter") to service such units, and if such election is made, the owner of such buildings will be responsible for payment of all water and wastewater services rendered to such buildings and units by the city. Further, the owner shall be responsible for all operation, maintenance, and replacement of water facilities on the user side of the master meter. 
(d)  Installation of a subunit meter for each dwelling unit is required at the time of construction for all new multifamily buildings where master meters are utilized. Purchase and installation are responsibility of the owner. The owner is responsible for any billing of residents based on subunit meters and may charge tenants separately for water and wastewater service, provided that the total amount of the charges to the tenants of such a building shall not exceed the total charges paid by the owner or operator for water and wastewater service for such building plus a reasonable fee for establishing, servicing and billing for water and wastewater service and provided, further, that the terms of the charges are disclosed to the tenants prior to any contractual agreement. 
(Code 1972, § 4-504; Ord. No. 86-10, 4-21-86; Ord. No. 2010-22, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 11-22. - Location. 
    The single water meter provided in this section shall be installed at or near the customer's property line as the public works director may designate. The city reserves the right to designate in all cases where the meter shall be located on the premises and to specify the amount of space required for installation and maintenance. 
(Code 1972, § 4-505; Ord. No. 2010-22, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 11-23. - Same-Defective; testing. 
(a)  Meters are installed to register the amount of water used. Bills shall be rendered according to meter reading. Should a meter fail to register properly the quantity used, it may be tested, as follows: 
(1)  The city will make a special water meter reading at the request of the consumer. 
(2)  Water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer upon payment to the city of the actual costs of making the test, provided, however, that if the meter is found to over-register beyond three (3) percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. 
(b)  If the seal of the meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of such consumer's previous bills and/or from other proper data. 
(Code 1972, §§ 4-506, 4-519) 
Sec. 11-24. - Tampering, interfering with meters, apparatus; unlawful use, diversion of service, damage to city property. 
    Whoever unlawfully and intentionally damages or destroys, or permits to be damaged or destroyed any meter, pipe, conduit or other apparatus belonging to the city and a part of its waterworks system, or unlawfully and intentionally prevents a water meter from duly registering the quantity of water supplied, or in any way interferes with its proper or just registration, or without the consent of the city, unlawfully and intentionally diverts water from any water main or pipe of the city, or otherwise unlawfully and intentionally uses or causes to be used, without the consent of the city, any water pumped or water distributed by it, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1972, § 4-507; Ord. No. 78-4, 11-20-78) 
State Law reference- Theft of services, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-5 et seq. 
Sec. 11-25. - Unlawful restoration of service. 
    Whenever water service shall have been discontinued or "cut off" by the city, it shall be unlawful for any person, except an authorized agent or employee of the city, to restore the service. 
(Code 1972, § 4-508; Ord. No. 78-4, 11-20-78) 
Sec. 11-26. - Applicability of minimum charges; illegally furnishing water to another; no fee service. 
    The minimum charge, as provided in the rate schedule, shall be made for each connection subscribed for. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only and, except for fire protection, the city shall not under any condition furnish water free of charge to any person. 
(Code 1972, § 4-512) 
Sec. 11-27. - City's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  The city shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed, and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. No service charge, other than the connection fee referred to in section 11-2, will be made for a five-eighths or three-fourths inch meter. A proportionately greater charge than the connection fee will be made for a meter of larger dimensions. 
(b)  The city may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable cost for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. 
(c)  The city may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the city's option, on the consumer's property within three (3) feet of the property line. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or pipings are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or back-flow. 
(e)  Under normal conditions the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-513) 
Cross reference- Grant of easement required for extension of service, § 11-5. 
Sec. 11-28. - Consumer's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of the consumer's household and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard for this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal or discontinuance of service. 
(b)  Where meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. 
(c)  The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the consumer's side of the meter. 
(d)  The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in accordance with the sanitary regulations of the state board of health. 
(e)  In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system and all applicants by becoming consumers of the city covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be consumers of the city they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. 
(Code 1972, § 4-514) 
Sec. 11-29. - Water use restrictions. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
    Address means the "house number" (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. 
    Declared drought response level means one (1) of four (4) levels of drought as declared by the director of the environmental protection division based on the severity of drought conditions, with one (1) being the least severe and four (4) being the most severe. 
    Environmental protection division (EPD) means an organizational unit of the State of Georgia Department of Natural Resources (DNR), which has responsibility for administration of the DNR's Rules for Outdoor Water Use (GA. Comp. R. and Regs Chapter 391-3-30) and for enforcement of such rules by water utilities, and their customers, permitted for water withdrawal or for operation of a drinking water utility. 
    Even-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. 
    Odd-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. 
(b)  Outdoor water use schedule during non-drought periods. At times when there are no declared drought conditions, persons may irrigate outdoors daily for purposes of planting, growing, managing or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. All other outdoor water use other than exempted activities shall occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. as follows: 
(1)  Odd-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use allowed on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. 
(2)  Even-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use is allowed on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. 
(c)  Outdoor water use schedule during declared drought response levels. During drought conditions pursuant to the declaration of the director of the EPD, outdoor water use shall occur only during scheduled hours on the scheduled days as allowed under that declaration or pursuant to the emergency provisions of this section. 
(d)  Exemptions. Outdoor water use restrictions shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A § 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local ordinances and board of health regulations; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater; 
(5)  Irrigation of personal food gardens; 
(6)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance or calibration of irrigations systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(e)  Right to curtail water usage during emergency conditions. 
(1)  Authority. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, the city manager, with the authorization of the mayor and city council, is empowered to implement special water conservation measures during emergency conditions. The type, nature, degree, penalty, commencement and duration of any restrictions or prohibitions are to be determined by the city manager and approved by the mayor and city council and in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7. 
(2)  Emergency conditions. For the purposes of this subsection only, emergency conditions shall include, but not be limited to times of drought low stream flows, interruptions in the raw water supply due to breaks or contamination, inability of the filter plants to meet demand, excessive losses or demands in the distribution system due to breaks, fires or other causes, contamination in the finished water, or any other purpose for which the curtailed use of water might be reasonably required in the best interest of public health, safety and welfare as determined by the city manager and in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7. 
(3)  Restrictions. The water conservation measures may include restrictions or prohibitions on nonessential uses such as (i) swimming pool filling, (ii) watering of lawns and gardens, (iii) washing of recreational or other vehicles, equipment, sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios and other paved areas, (iv) recreational uses, and (v) other uses which the city manager may deem to be nonessential. 
(4)  Notice. A notice of the restrictions or prohibitions imposed under this subsection shall be published in the official organ of the city in a non-legal section. The notice shall set forth the specific nature of the restrictions or prohibitions, the reasons for the imposition of the restrictions or prohibitions, the date upon which the restrictions or prohibitions become effective, and their duration. The restrictions and prohibitions shall become effective no sooner than the first day following the publication date of the first notice. The notice shall be published once a month while the restrictions and prohibitions are in effect. 
(f)  Enforcement. 
(1)  No customer shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in or promulgated pursuant to the Code of Ordinances of the city, specifically including this section. 
(2)  The code enforcement office of the city community development department, by and through its officers and other personnel, shall be the enforcement authority for this section. The city manager may also authorize other city departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(3)  Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the municipal court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. 
(g)  Application and jurisdiction. This article shall apply to all water customers of the city, or their property served with water by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-521; Ord. No. 86-18, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 2007-09, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2007-16, 8-20-07; Ord. No. 2010-58, § 1, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 11-30. - Fire line connection fees. 
(a)  This section shall apply to all new connections of fire lines to the water service of the city. For purposes of this section, a "fire line" shall be defined as any water line designed and intended to service fire protection devices, including, but not limited to, sprinkler systems. 
(b)  Each consumer desiring to connect a six-inch fire line to the water service of the city shall pay a connection fee of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) upon connection to the water service. The total cost of construction [of] said fire line, including materials and installation, shall be the responsibility of the consumer. The plans and specifications for said fire line, as well as the choice of the contractor installing said fire line, shall be approved by the city prior to construction of said fire line. 
(c)  Each consumer desiring to connect an eight-inch fire line to the water service of the city shall pay a connection fee of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) upon connection to the water service. The total cost of construction [of] said fire line, including materials and installation, shall be the responsibility of the consumer. The plans and specifications for said fire line, as well as the choice of the contractor installing said fire line, shall be approved by the city prior to construction of said fire line. 
(Ord. No. 97-5, 4-7-97) 
Secs. 11-31-11-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Littering, etc., § 10-20 et seq; license for solid waste collectors, § 12-150 et seq. 
State Law reference- Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 11-40. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Garbage: All vegetable matter, food scraps, newspapers, ice cream cartons, all tissue paper and other waste material from kitchens, grocery stores, butcher shops, restaurants, cafes, drugstores, hotels, roominghouses and boardinghouses. 
    Recyclable materials means plastic beverage bottles and jugs, glass bottles and jars, corrugated cardboard, newspaper, bimetal and aluminum cans, magazines, telephone books, automobile batteries, used motor oil, dry paint cans, metal, and large appliances. 
    Rubbish: All plastics, glass, metal cans, throw-away baby diapers, dog and cat litter, bundled newspapers, razor blades, wire, and all throw-away bottles. 
    Trash: Paint cans, boxes, old rags, yard cleanings, grass clippings, leaves, pine straw, broken toys, tree trimmings, grills, and old garbage cans. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 1, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-41. - Refuse not acceptable for collection by city. 
    The following refuse shall be considered to be not acceptable for collection by the city: 
(1)  Dangerous materials or substances, such as poisons, acids, caustics, infected materials and explosives. 
(2)  Unusual quantities of materials resulting from the repair, excavation or construction of buildings or structures such as earth, plaster, mortar and roofing materials. 
(3)  Materials which have not been prepared for collection in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(4)  The solid wastes resulting from industrial processes. 
(5)  Tree trimmings where trees are trimmed or cut for compensation whether the compensation be in cash or in the wood from the trees trimmed or cut except in the case of a natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-42. - Inspection. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the director of the utilities and public works department or designated representative, to make inspection trips at regular intervals to determine whether or not garbage, trash, recyclable materials and rubbish are being properly collected, removed and disposed of as required by this Code or any applicable health ordinance. In the event it is found that such ordinance or regulations are being violated, appropriate and timely action shall be taken to insure full compliance with the provisions. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 2, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-43. - Service required; exceptions; penalties; fee increases. 
(a)  Every household in the city shall subscribe to the sanitation service provided or contracted by the city for the collection of garbage, trash, recyclable materials and rubbish. A household may be exempted by providing a certified statement as to the method of disposal of the household wastes, and by applying for the temporary suspension of service as provided below. The disposal must be in accordance with the state law requiring safe, sanitary and adequate disposal. 
(b)  Those persons found guilty of improper disposal of their household waste shall be fined the maximum allowed by law per occurrence. Improper disposal shall include placing waste in commercial dumpsters, along roadways, vacant lots, another person's cart, and similar situations. 
(c)  The monthly sanitation fee shall be established by resolution, which may be amended from time to time, and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. The fee shall be adjusted automatically to account for any increases in dumping fees. 
(d)  Temporary suspension of service and of monthly sanitation fee for unoccupied residences. 
(1)  A city resident whose residential unit will be unoccupied for more than thirty (30) consecutive days may make application with city hall for a temporary suspension of the service and fee. Such application may be made by the resident on a form made available by city hall. The length of suspension of the service and fee shall not exceed six (6) months unless authorized by the public works director. 
(2)  Within fourteen (14) days of the decision by city hall, any resident aggrieved by a decision to refuse to suspend may appeal that decision to the public works director for a final administrative hearing and determination. The public works director shall conduct an informal administrative hearing within ten (10) business days of the resident appealing the original decision to not suspend. The resident and the city shall have the right to present sworn testimony and evidence. Upon the final administrative decision of the public works director to approve or deny the suspension under this chapter, such decision being in writing and including a notice of the decision and reasons therefore to the resident, the applicant may appeal the decision to the Cobb County Superior Court by writ of certiorari. There shall be no suspension of the service or fee during the appeal notification period or while an appeal is pending before the public works director. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, §§ 1-3, 2-16-87; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 2, 11-15-10; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 3, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-44. - Collection to be carried on in systematic and efficient manner. 
    The collection, removal and disposal of all garbage, trash, recyclable materials and rubbish shall be carried on in a systematic and efficient manner, keeping the entire city in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 4, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-45. - Plastic carts-Provided by city. 
(a)  Plastic wheeled carts shall be required for street-side collection service. The responsibility for obtaining such cart shall be upon the owner or occupant of the premises desiring and otherwise eligible, by the terms of this article, for street-side collection service. The owner or occupant of the premises is required to contact the department of public works and request the delivery of a cart. 
(b)  Additional carts may be purchased from the city by the owner or occupant and will be serviced according to the provision of this article subject to the following limit, which is hereby imposed upon the number of carts that will be serviced by the city: 
Number of Carts 
(1)  Residences ..... 2 
(2)  Commercial establishments ..... 2 
(3)  Multiple housing units and trailer courts less than ten (10) separate units, per unit ..... 2 
(4)  Multiple housing units and trailer courts of ten (10) or more housing units shall be required to use dumpster boxes. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-45.1. - Recycling. 
    In order to protect the environment by conserving natural resources and preserving rapidly dwindling landfill space as well as minimizing waste disposal costs, the city encourages recycling for all residential occupants within the city limits to recycle all recyclable materials. 
(1)  Collection and container requirements for recyclable materials will be the same as those outlined in sections 11-45, 11-46, and 11-48 of this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 2014-033, § 5, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-46. - Same-Placement for collection. 
    All refuse, ashes, garbage, trash and recyclable materials shall be placed in carts for collection. The carts shall be placed at street-side for collection purposes. The collection schedule shall be announced by the department of utilities and public works. If the carts are not near the street-side at collection time, this will indicate no service is needed. 
(Ord. No 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 6, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-47. - Same-Non-street-side collection. 
    Non-street-side collection will be provided for households within the city limits if all persons abiding in the household meet the following conditions: 
(1)  Physically unable to walk a cart to the curb, due to being confined to a bed or confined to a wheelchair, or, 
(2)  Physically unable to roll a garbage cart to street side, as certified by a medical doctor, or, 
(3)  Older than sixty-five (65) years of age, 
(4)  For those persons who are head of household and age seventy (70) years or older, backyard service will be provided at a rate of fifty (50) percent of the normal residential customer rate. 
    Each household desiring to receive backyard service must apply to city hall with the appropriate information. The household information will be verified and a decision provided. If the applicant is denied, the decision may be appealed to the governing body. 
    The exception will be reevaluated each twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 87-9, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 89-15, §§ 1, 2, 5-15-89) 
Sec. 11-48. - Same-Time limit at street-side. 
    Carts shall be placed at street-side no earlier than 8:00 p.m. on the day before the scheduled collection day and carts shall be removed from street-side no later than 9:00 p.m. on the day of collection. Violations of this section shall be reported to the department of utilities and public works. Upon receiving a complaint, the department shall investigate such complaint. Upon finding a violation, the offending party shall have forty-eight (48) hours after receiving the notice to remove carts. Any party failing to remove carts from street-side within the specified time after receiving the notice shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 7, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-49. - Same-Replacement. 
(a)  The department of utilities and public works shall have the authority to require the replacement of any cart that is so worn or damaged as to hinder the effective street-side collection program. 
(b)  Any cart that is damaged or destroyed through the negligence or misuse of the city shall be replaced at the expense of the city. The department of utilities and public works shall have the authority to determine in each case of damage whether the damage is sufficient to require replacement. 
(c)  In all other cases in which a cart is rendered unserviceable, the city may replace the cart and charge the property owner for all replacement costs incurred in connection with the replacement. 
(d)  The property owner shall be responsible for replacement of any lost or stolen cart. 
(e)  Deposits for city garbage carts being returned will be based upon the condition of the cart returned, ordinary wear and tear excepted. 
(f)  Subject to availability, the city may allow those residents utilizing city garbage service to obtain a used garbage cart for a deposit of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per cart. All other provisions of city's waste collection and disposal ordinance applicable to new carts shall continue to apply to any used carts obtained under this provision. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 93-23, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 95-11, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 11-50. - Same-Not to be over-filled; placement of extra trash in disposable bags or boxes. 
    Carts shall not be filled to overflowing. When carts are fully loaded, extra trash, garbage, refuse or ashes may be placed in disposable containers and placed next to carts for collection. The owner/occupant may place tree limbs, branches, tree cuttings and vines beside the curb for collection by request to city hall and payment of fee. Such tree limbs, branches, tree cuttings and vines shall be no longer than four (4) feet and no more than seventy-five (75) pounds in weight. The city shall not collect trimmings where trees are trimmed or cut for compensation whether the compensation be in cash or in the wood from the trees trimmed or cut except in the case of a natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 8, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-51. - Containers for trash and cold ashes, generally. 
    Trash or cold ashes may be separately placed in disposable containers. All such receptacles shall be removed with the contents. Trash and ashes shall not be placed in any disposable containers that are so worn or defective that the contents leak or spill out. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-52. - Material not to be collected from premises where violation exists. 
    Trash and refuse collectors are not required to collect from premises where the provisions of this article are violated. The failure to collect any trash or garbage from the premises because of a violation of the provisions of this article shall not relieve the persons responsible for such violation from prosecution and penalty therefor. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-53. - Confinement of animals which interfere with collectors. 
    Occupants of premises shall facilitate collections of garbage, trash, recyclable materials and refuse by confining animals which might interfere with collectors. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 9, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-54. - Frequency of collections. 
    Except as otherwise in this article provided and except in the case of emergency arising from an act of God or under circumstances over which the director has no control, the department shall collect, remove and dispose of all household refuse and trash in the city once per week. 
(1)  If a holiday should fall during the week in which an area is due a regular collection, such collection shall be made on the following work day, unless otherwise announced by the department of public works. 
(2)  Refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, furniture and similar items will be collected only by appointment made with the department. Collections shall be made at the property line and such items shall be placed at the property line no sooner than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the appointed time of collection. The occupant of the premises shall be responsible to see that locks or doors of refrigerators, ice boxes or containers are removed. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-55. - Dumpster boxes. 
    In the case of multiple housing units of ten (10) or more individual units, trailer courts of ten (10) or more separate units and in the case of commercial establishments when the limit imposed by section 11-45 is exceeded, dumpster boxes shall be used. In the case of multiple housing units and trailer courts, of ten (10) or more units, when dumpster boxes are required, there shall be one (1) six-cubic-yard box for every ten (10) units. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-55.1. - Disposition of industrial waste. 
    Industrial waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the operator of the factory, plant or enterprise creating or causing the same in accordance with regulations promulgated by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-56. - Disposition of building rubbish. 
    All trash, debris, tree limbs, stumps, brush, logs, building scraps, leaves, and other such debris and rubbish shall be removed from the construction site or burned in accordance with the county fire safety code after a burning permit is issued in writing by the county fire department. 
(a)  No debris of any kind shall be buried at the site of any construction or development. 
(b)  A grading permit must be issued by the city public works department prior to any grading, as provided in the unified development code. 
(c)  No fill shall be made until after inspection by the public works department in accordance with the provisions of the unified development code. 
(d)  Those persons found guilty of improper disposal of building waste shall be fined the maximum allowed by law per occurrence and be required to promptly remove rubbish, trash, debris or other waste. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 88-25, § 1, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 88-34, §§ 1-10, 12-5-88; Ord. No. 91-20, 7-15-91; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 3, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-57. - Disposition so as to avoid pick-up service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any garbage, dirt, trash, dead animals or other refuse in any container provided or maintained by any owner, occupant, or tenant or lessee using or occupying any building, house or structure within the city for residences, schools, churches, colleges, lodges, commercial businesses in any quantity to avoid providing or subscribing to a service for the pick-up of garbage, trash, dirt, dead animals or other refuse at the residence or the site of the operations of the business of such persons. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-58. - Depositing refuse in container of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or intentionally deposit garbage, trash, recyclable materials or rubbish into the garbage container of another person. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-22-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 10, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-59. - Garbage and trash to be drained or wrapped before placing therein. 
(a)  All garbage or trash that is mixed with water or other liquids shall be drained before being put in the garbage or trash container. 
(b)  All animal matter that is subject to decomposition shall be well-wrapped in paper or other material before being deposited in such container. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-60. - Tampering with contents. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to uncover, pilfer, dig into, turn over or in any manner tamper with any refuse container belonging to another. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the use of public refuse containers for their intended purpose. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-61. - Collection procedures; service deposit. 
(a)  To avoid duplication in billing and as a convenience to the public, the fee for collection service shall be included on the monthly water bill. Should this service be rendered to any owner, occupant, tenant or lessee not being served by the city public water system, such charges for this service shall be rendered separately on a monthly basis. 
(b)  Any person desiring to receive collection service shall pay a deposit, the deposit to be held by the city until after the rendering of the final bill due the city for services. The amount of the deposit will be determined by the service rate of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 2-16-87) 
Sec. 11-62. - Service charges. 
    The fee charged by the city for deposit and collection of garbage, trash and recyclable materials shall be determined by the city. Rates shall be as posted at city hall and shall be reviewed at least annually. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 11, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-63. - Private collectors prohibited. 
    No private collector of garbage shall operate in the city. The collection of garbage shall be exclusively a municipal function. The only private collector of recyclable materials operating in the city shall be the private collector authorized by the city to collect recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 2014-033, § 12, 10-6-14 ) 
Sec. 11-64. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of the utilities public works department to enforce these rules and regulations, and in performance of this duty the director or such director's authorized representative is hereby authorized to enter, at any reasonable hour, any premises as may be necessary for such enforcement. The chief of police or his representative shall issue actual citations upon the request of the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. No. 86-24, 9-2-86) 
Sec. 11-65. - Packaging of garbage, rubbish and trash within Central Business District. 
    In addition to any and all other requirements of law, including any and all other requirements of this article, all commercial establishments (including, without limitation, all office, institutional, retail, commercial and industrial uses) located in any CBD zoning district which occupy or control single buildings containing ten thousand (10,000) square feet or more of floor space, or multiple buildings aggregating ten thousand (10,000) square feet or more floor space, shall compact, to the smallest practicable volume, all garbage, trash and rubbish to be collected by the city. 
    Rubbish may be stored for collection in paperboard boxes or other disposable containers sufficiently strong to contain the rubbish. 
    Disposable paper or plastic bags of a type, size and material designed for solid waste disposal may be used to contain garbage and/or refuse for storage and collection, provided they are unbroken, sealed, and loaded in such a manner that normal handling cannot cause the bag to rupture or open. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, 1-15-90) 
Secs. 11-66-11-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Sewage disposal, § 10-40 et seq. 

Sec. 11-70. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Act or the Act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Chemical oxygen demand (COD): A measure of oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidant. 
    Cooling water: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Environmental protection agency (EPA): The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate the term may also be use as a designation for the administrator or other duly authorized official of said agency. 
    Floatable oil: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
    Holding tank waste: Any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
    Indirect discharge: The discharge of the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) or (c) of the act (33 U.S.C. 1317), into the POTW (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
    Industrial user: A source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to section 402 of the act (33 U.S.C. 1342). 
    Industrial waste surcharge: The charge made in excess of the sewer service charge for all wastewater over and above normal wastewater. 
    Industrial wastes: The wastewater from industrial processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
    Interference: The inhibition or disruption of the POTW treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the county's NPDES permit. The term includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the POTW in accordance with section 405 of the act (33 U.S.C. 1345) or any criteria, guidelines or regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to title IV of SWDA) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the POTW. 
    Manager: The public works director of the city. 
    National categorical pretreatment standard or pretreatment standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with section 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 U.S.C. 1347) which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
    National pollution discharge elimination system or NPDES permit: A permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the act (33 U.S.C 1342). 
    Natural outlet: Any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal wastewater: Wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers in which the average concentration of total suspended solids and BOD is not more than three hundred (300) mg/l, total phosphorus is not more than fifteen (15) mg/l, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more eighteen (18) mg/l; and total flow is not more than twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day. 
    pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in grams per liter of solution. 
    Pollutant: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
    Pollution: The manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. 
    Pretreatment or treatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or by process changes or other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR section 403.6(d). 
    Properly shredded garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half-inch in any dimension. 
    Publicly owned treatment works (POTW): A treatment works as defined by section 212 of the act (U.S.C. 1292) which is owned in this instance by the county or the city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. 
    Suspended solids: Total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
    Toxic pollutant: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the EPA. 
    User: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the POTW. 
    Wastewater: The spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and storm-water that may be present. 
    Watercourse: A natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 1, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-71. - Abbreviations. 
    The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings:

(Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-72. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
(a)  Duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing pertinent to discharge to the sewer system in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to herein, the authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to said employees, and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by said employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions. 
(c)  Said duly authorized employees of the city shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds an easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the waste water facilities lying with said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the easement involved. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 3, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-73. - Compliance with regulatory requirements. 
(a)  General: The provisions of this article shall not be deemed as alleviating compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. Specific user charge and industrial cost recovery requirements, promulgated pursuant to Public Law 92-500, shall be considered as a part of this article upon official adoption. All nonresidential users will be required to comply with pretreatment standards as outlined in title 40 of the CFR, part 403. 
(b)  Federal categorical pretreatment standards: Upon the promulgation of the federal categorical pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed hereunder for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed hereunder. The manager shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting requirements under 40 CFR, section 403.12. 
(c)  Modifications of federal categorical pretreatment standards: In the event the county modifies said standards in accordance with the law in such cases provided, such modifications shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed hereunder. 
(d)  State requirements: State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal or county requirements and limitations or those hereunder. 
(e)  Right to revise to more stringent limitations: The city reserves the right to establish by ordinance more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the wastewater disposal system if deemed necessary to comply with objectives stated in the preamble hereof. 
(f)  Excessive discharge: No user shall ever increase the use of process water or, in any way, attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in the federal categorical pretreatment standards, or in any other pollutant-specific limitations developed by the city, county or state, unless specifically allowed in the categorical pretreatment standards established by EPA. 
(g)  Accidental discharges: 
(1)  Protection: Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this article. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's own cost and expense. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the city for review, and shall be approved by same before construction of the facility. All existing users shall complete such a plan within four (4) months after adoption hereof. No user who commences contribution to the POTW after the effective date hereof shall be permitted to introduce pollutants into the system until accidental discharge procedures have been approved by the city. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the industrial user from the responsibility to modify the user's facility as necessary to meet the requirements hereof. In the case of an accidental discharge, it is the responsibility of the user to immediately telephone and notify the POTW (the county, as well as the city) of the incident. The notification shall include location of discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume, and corrective actions. 
(2)  Written notice: Within five (5) days following an accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the POTW (the county, as well as the city) a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills or any other damage to person or property; nor shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties or other liability which may be imposed hereunder or other applicable law. 
(3)  Notice to employees: A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of a dangerous discharge or accidental discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who may cause or suffer such a dangerous or accidental discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 4, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-74. - Cause for service disconnection. 
    The city reserves the right to terminate water and wastewater disposal services and disconnect a customer from the system when: 
(1)  Acids or chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment process are released into the sewer causing rapid deterioration of these structures or interfering with proper conveyance and treatment of wastewater; or 
(2)  A governmental agency informs the city that the effluent from the wastewater treatment plant is no longer of a quality permitted for discharge into a watercourse, and it is found that the customer is delivering wastewater to the system that cannot be sufficiently treated or requires treatment that is not provided by the county as normal domestic treatment; or 
(3)  The customer: 
a.  Discharges industrial waste or wastewater that is in violation of the permit issued by the approving authority; 
b.  Discharges wastewater at an uncontrolled, variable rate in sufficient quantity to cause an imbalance in the wastewater treatment systems; 
c.  Fails to pay monthly bills for water and sanitary sewer services when due; or 
d.  Repeats a discharge of prohibited wastes into public sewers. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 5, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-75. - Unauthorized connections prohibited; penalty. 
    No person shall make an unauthorized water or sewer connection or obtain unauthorized water or sewer services. Persons so obtaining unauthorized connection or service shall be subject to the maximum penalty fee allowed by law and shall also be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 6, 4-7-86; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 4, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 11-76. - Violations. 
(a)  Violations a misdemeanor: Violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor punishable under the laws of the state and under the charter and Code of the city. 
(b)  Suspension of service: The city may suspend the wastewater treatment service and/or wastewater contribution permit when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of the city, in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or to the environment, causes interference to the POTW, or causes the county to violate any conditions of its NPDES permit. 
(c)  Elimination of contribution required: Any person notified of a suspension of the wastewater treatment service and/or the wastewater contribution permit shall immediately stop or eliminate the contribution. In the event of a failure of the person to comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the city shall take such steps as deemed necessary, including initiation of legal action and immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW system or endangerment to any individuals. The city shall reinstate the wastewater contribution permit and/or the wastewater treatment service upon proof of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge. A detailed written statement submitted by the user describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence shall be submitted to the city within fifteen (15) calendar days of the date of occurrence. 
(d)  Permit revocation: Any user who violates the following conditions of this section or applicable state and federal regulations is subject to having such person's permit revoked in accordance with the procedures of this section: 
(1)  Failure of a user to report factually the wastewater constituents and characteristics of such user's discharge. 
(2)  Failure of the user to report significant changes in operations, or wastewater constituents and characteristics. 
(3)  Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection or monitoring. 
(4)  Violation of conditions of the permit. 
(e)  Service of notice; plan of correction: Whenever the city finds that any user has violated or is violating this article, wastewater contribution permit, or any prohibitions, limitation or requirements contained herein, the city may serve upon such person a written notice stating the nature of the violation. Within thirty (30) days of the date of the notice, a plan for the satisfactory correction thereof shall be submitted to the city by the user. Each quarter, the city will publish in the local newspapers the list of violators of this article for that quarter. 
(f)  Verbal, written notice of violation: In the event of violation of this article, the authorized employees of the city may verbally instruct the owner as to the necessary corrective action. If the owner fails to carry out verbal instructions in a timely manner or if a serious violation or hazard to public health exists, the city may issue to the owner a written order stating the nature of the violation, the corrective action and the time limit for completing the corrective action. This time limit will be not less than twenty-four (24) hours nor more than six (6) months depending upon the type and severity of the violation. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The record of the mailing of said notice or order shall be prima facie evidence thereof, and failure of said owner or owners to receive same shall in no way affect the validity of any proceeding conducted pursuant to this article. 
(g)  Legal action authorized: If any person discharges sewage, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater disposal system contrary to the provisions of this article, federal or state pretreatment requirements, or any order of the city, the city attorney may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in the appropriate court. 
(h)  Fines: 
(1)  Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city or who wilfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than the maximum permitted by law for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. 
(2)  Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, record, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article or wastewater contribution permits, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(3)  A person violating any provision of this section authorizing the aforementioned action by the city shall be charged the normal and usual charges for discontinuance and disconnection of said water and sewer services and the usual charges for recommencing said water and sewer services. 
(Ord. No. 86-9, § 7, 4-7-86) 
Sec. 11-77. - Permit required for industrial sewer user.
